resources.string: Select which available event types to display
Export the CSV to a file

Mood Diary by Kristian Gunstone

This is my go at making a mood tracking app for Android.
It's my first official Android as well as Java app, so there's been a lot to learn. I'm sure the code can be massively improved with some care and attention from someone who might know better; perhaps that will be the future me. As I've had an immediate need for this app - not finding anything satisfactory on play - it's been rapidly developed, using some ideas I thought up years ago.

The idea comes from a paper-submission form I've used, which had fields for writing down certain things such as mood in a scale from 'very depressed' to 'very elevated', anxiety level, and a few more. After that, I continued using a similar system, but in textfiles. I didn't need much more; only analyzing the data was left out. For that I wrote some elaborate python scripts to parse the text and write json, but it just got a bit out of hand; boredom preceeded necessity.

Now I've fallen behind on the logging because of the effort in adding an entry, or not being near a computer with the files, and that's not cool.

So, here it is. The app itself is pretty simple: add a few measurements you want to note down, and a reminder or two. At the specified time, Mood Diary will appear, asking you to submit the measurements. When it's time to interpret the data, export the entire database, or make a custom CSV which you can import to your favourite spreadsheet or plotting software.
